ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: It was a really good opportunity to learn about research that other graduate students are working on and to get feedback on my own ongoing research. It was particularly useful presenting work to people who do not work in my own area of specialisation.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It was good that it was flexible to the students' needs (i.e. we did not force meetings when nobody wanted to present), and one paper per student was appropriate. I also really liked that the course instructor facilitated inviting other professors to come in to comment on student papers and otherwise participate in the Q&A. The main downside is that not enough students participate. If only a small group of graduate students participate, that's a lot of pressure on the same few number of graduate students to give helpful comments on every other paper. Not only would it be more useful to have more students involved for whoever is presenting at any given time, but it would also decrease the workload on any one student - making it easier to take this alongside other commitments - and it would also do a lot for the graduate academic community.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. It think the more graduate students involved in the course, the better.
